text.0: this is the ancient and accepted pathway by which all gods have come into existence.
text.1: hereby could one be born though waxen mighty let him not otherwise destroy his mother.
text.2: not this way go i forth hard is the passage forth from the side obliquely will i issue.
text.3: much that is yet undone must i accomplish one must i combat and the other question.
text.4: he bent his eye upon the dying mother my word i now withdraw that way i follow.
text.5: in tvaṣṭars dwelling india drank the soma a hundredworth of juice pressed from the mortar.
text.6: what strange act shall he do he whom his mother bore for a thousand months and many autumns.
text.7: no peer hath he among those born already nor among those who shall be born hereafter.
text.8: deeming him a reproach his mother hid him indra endowed with all heroic valour.
text.9: then up he sprang himself assumed his vesture and filled as soon as born the earth and heaven.
text.10: with lively motion onward flow these waters the holy ones shouting as twere together.
text.11: ask them to tell thee what the floods are saying what girdling rock the waters burst asunder.
text.12: are they addressing him with words of welcome will the floods take on them the shame of indra.
text.13: with his great thunderbolt my son hath slaughtered vṛtra and set these rivers free to wander.
text.14: i cast thee from me minethy youthful mother thee mine own offspring kusava hath swallowed.
text.15: to him mine infant were the waters gracious indra my son rose up in conquering vigour.
text.16: thou art mine own o maghavan whom vyaṁsa struck to the ground and smote thy jaws in pieces.
text.17: but smitten through the mastery thou wonnest and with thy bolt the dāsas head thou crushedst.
text.18: the heifer hath brought forth the strong the mighty the unconquerable bull the furious indra.
text.19: the mother left her unlicked calf to wander seeking himself the path that he would follow.
text.20: then to her mighty child the mother turned her saying my son these deities forsake thee.
text.21: then indra said about to slaughter vṛtra o my friend vṛtra stride full boldly forward.
text.22: who was he then who made thy mother widow who sought to stay thee lying still or moving.
text.23: what god when by the foot thy sire thou tookest and slewest was at hand to give thee comfort.
text.24: in deep distress i cooked a dogs intestines among the gods i found not one to comfort.
text.25: my consort i beheld in degradation the falcon then brought me the pleasant soma.
